You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a moderately cautious undergraduate student who prefers some degree of security and predictability, I would consider the long-term payoff over 75 rounds to make my decision.

However, there is a risk that my opponent might exploit me by choosing R consistently, earning 3375$, while I earn only 2850$. To mitigate this risk, I would choose B in the first few rounds to observe their strategy. If they choose R every time, I would switch to R to maximize my earnings; if they switch to R after a few rounds, I would continue choosing B. In either case, I aim to maintain a balance between security (earning 3490$) and minimizing the risk of losing significant amount of money.

In this game, there is no way to know my opponent's strategy for sure, but based on my cautious nature, I would choose B as my initial move to gather information and adapt my strategy accordingly.
